ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter: my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_ possibilities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing messages where the server

Peter:

my comment here is not about designing messages where _all_
possibi=
lities exist at _all_ times, but is instead about designing
messages where =
the server can indicate to the client what options are
available and valid =
"at this point in time." (i.e. you don't see the
"details" link in the mess=
age because you are not yet logged in" or
"you don't see the "markup for ad=
ding an invoice because you are not
authorized to do so" or 'You don't see =
the link for reports because
the reports are not yet avaialble" and so fort=
h).

Here are some examples:
HTML.IMG
means "retrieve the resource and embe=
d it in the page (don't navigate to it)"

X.INCLUDE
means "retrieve the res=
ource and embed it in the page (don't navigate to it)"

HTML.A
means "navig=
ate to the resource (don't embed it)"

ATOM.LINK@rel=3D"alternate"
means "n=
avigate to the resource (don't embed it)"

HTML.FORM@method=3D":get"
means =
"collect the arguments, construct a URI and navigate to that
resource using=
 the HTTP method "get" (don't make a body w/ the args)"

HTML.FORM@method=
=3D"post"
means "collect the arguments, construct a body and navigate to th=
at
resource using the HTTP method "post" (don't construct a URI w/ the
args=
)"

ATOM:LINK@rel=3D"edit"
means "use this link to PUT or DELETE the indica=
ted resource using
guidlines set out in AtomPub

none of the RDF media type=
s i have encountered have these affordances
built in; there is no universal=
 way for servers to inform clients of
the valid/appropriate possibilities a=
t any point in time. Clients must
have this information hard-coded instead.=


FWIW, Mark Baker built the RDF Forms[1] ontology, but i've not seen
that =
in production use. I've seen an attempt to mimic HTTP GET & POST
using an R=
DF conversion[1], but not seen that in production use.


[1] http://www.mar=
kbaker.ca/2003/05/RDF-Forms/
[2] http://www.lsrn.org/semweb/rdfpost.html

m=
ca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/fo=
af.rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 15:15, Peter Williams <pezra@barelyeno=
ugh.org> wrote:
> I'm not sure
>
> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:08 PM, mike am=
undsen <mamund@...> wrote:
>> However, I've not yet been able to desi=
gn an RDF media type that
>> _also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e=
. navigate|embed,
>> protocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.=
) that a wide
>> range of clients can consume (even those not "interested i=
n" the
>> protocol semantics available in the RDF media type).
>
> I don't =
think i understand the issues you mention.
>
> =A0* I dont know what you me=
an by "navigate|embed" means. If i have an
> HTTP link to a resource then i=
 can, by virtue of the uniform
> interface, try to navigate to that url. If=
 the resource does not
> support GET it will respond with 405. Embedding is=
 a very different
> issue that seem deeply related to the media type. For e=
xample it is
> trivial with RDF-ish media types and impossible with HTML (a=
t least
> formally).
>
> =A0* I am not sure why protocol method is importan=
t. We have the uniform
> interface so any method may be called on any resou=
rce. It might be a
> useful hint sometimes but is it every required?
>
> =
=A0* I don't know of any form-ish vocabularies for RDF, but it doesn't
> se=
em like that would be all that difficult to implement. That being
> said, i=
 don't feel like that not having forms is a show stopper for a
> media type=
.
>
> =A0* Idempotency is defined by the uniform interface (at least in HTT=
P),
> not by the media type. Why would a media type need to encode this typ=
e
> of information?
>
> Maybe i am missing your point?
>
> I don't know if =
RDF-ish approaches are a good way to build RESTful
> HTTP systems but they =
seem like they might be. `@rel` really is very
> similar to the property id=
 in RDF. Otherwise RDFa would not be able to
> use it for that purpose so e=
ffortlessly.
>
> I suppose RDF does make finding navigable links in a tad m=
ore
> difficult. You have to look at all the properties and find the ones
>=
 whose value is a resource, rather than having a separate list of
> propert=
ies with resources as values vs properties with other types of
> values. OT=
OH, I have always thought it weird that the REST community
> treats links a=
 magically special. Unifying the model make me more
> comfortable: a link i=
s nothing more, or less, than a property of a
> resource whose value is ano=
ther resource.
>
> Peter
>
>> RDFa seems to come the closest to mixing both=
 design goals and it
>> starts from the hypermedia design then adds RDF ele=
ments. =A0I haven't
>> found an inverse of the RDFa model.
>>
>> mca
>> htt=
p://amundsen.com/blog/
>> http://twitter.com@mamund
>> http://mamund.com/fo=
af.rdf#me
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@smi=
y.org> wrote:
>>> Hi Markus,
>>>
>>> well, from my POV (a Semantic Web bias=
ed one), I would agree. However, I
>>> always got and get the impression th=
at the REST/hypermedia community
>>> doesn't agree on this equation*.
>>> I=
 guess, it has something to do with the hypermedia support that
>>> surroun=
ds the utilisation of link relation types, i.e. they are values
>>> of rel =
attributes of tags, e.g., "link", "a", or "area". These tags and
>>> their =
attributes define the processing (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of
>>> referr=
ed resources (in the media type definition). Furthermore, in such
>>> a hyp=
ermedia context a client should know whether it is a navigational
>>> link,=
 an embedded link, etc.
>>> On the other side, RDF is a data model or knowl=
edge representation
>>> structure, which should be embeddable into other ex=
isting hypermedia
>>> media types (as it already can done with RDFa, see XH=
TML+RDFa). So RDF
>>> serialisation (/representation) formats doesn't need =
this
>>> functionalities themselves.
>>> I somehow believe that is better, =
if these two concerns are separable
>>> and one could mix them as needed, b=
ecause not every client needs the
>>> knowledge of the underlying resource/=
model description.
>>>
>>> Cheers,
>>>
>>>
>>> Bo
>>>
>>>
>>> *) which is s=
o obvious from my POV :) (because it's all about binary
>>> relations in th=
at context)
>>>
>>> PS: Interesting to read in that context:
>>> http://www=
.amundsen.com/blog/archives/1065 +
>>> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archive=
s/1083
>>>
>>> PPS: I still believe that H-Factor is a very good measuremen=
t for
>>> hypermedia, see http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
>>>
>>>
>=

ations should any different. A predicate (or a labeled edge in a graph)

lationship of node B to node A I also know how to process it or if I would
=
>>>> be interested in following that link.

>>> =A0> Hi Markus,
>>>> =A0>
>>>> =A0> link relation type definition are n=
ot (RDF) property definitions. Where
>>>> =A0> the latter ones define somet=
hing about the properties (relations) it
>>>> =A0> themselves, the former o=
nes include something about the processing of
>>>> =A0> these relations, i.=
e., how to handle the referred object.
>>>> =A0> To sum up, link relation t=
ype definitions are usually orthogonal to
>>>> =A0> (RDF) property definiti=
ons. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed
>>>> =A0> discussion on this issue =
and related ones.
>>>> =A0>

>>>=

"http://www.markus-lanthaler.com/"

is (incomplete) JSON-LD document would tell you that there's a JSON
>>>> =
=A0> object
>>>> =A0> > which has a key "homepage" that represents a homepa=
ge according to
>>>> =A0> the FOAF
>>>> =A0> > vocabulary - that's the rel =
part, isn't it!? The value of it is
>>>> =A0> > "http://www.markus-lanthale=
r.com/". The coercion in the context tells
>>>> =A0> a
>>>> =A0> > JSON-LD =
parser that it is an IRI and not just a string and thus
>>>> =A0> allows a
=
>>>> =A0> > client to follow that link.
>>>> =A0> >
>>>> =A0> > See also Ma=
nu Sporny's comment on Mark Notthingsham's blog post about

king in JSON" [1]. I think there is still some confusion about
>>>> =A0> wh=
at

p://www.mnot.net/blog/2011/11/25/linking_in_json#comment-1737
